metadata.title: Scoliosis
anatomical location body part affected: Spine, usually thoracic and lumbar regions; rib cage
description: Scoliosis is lateral deviation of the spine from the normal vertical line of > 10°(2) –Scoliosis affects 1.5% to 3% of adolescents(2)
Functional scoliosis – a reversible lateral curvature of the spine, dependent on posture and caused by compensation for another musculoskeletal condition

Structural scoliosis – a lateral curvature of the spine, which is not dependent upon posture, with definitive musculoskeletal changes (e.g., rotation of the vertebrae) –Idiopathic scoliosis (vast majority of cases) – can be classified by age of onset(4) -Infantile scoliosis – occurs by the age of 3 years -Juvenile scoliosis – occurs between the ages of 3 years and 10 years -Adolescent scoliosis – occurs after 10 years of age -Adult idiopathic scoliosis – begins or is diagnosed after puberty after complete skeletal growth(15) –Congenital scoliosis, including scoliosis associated with dysmorphic syndromes such as Prader-Willi syndrome(7) –Neuromuscular scoliosis –Degenerative scoliosis
The different types of structural scoliosis have different etiologies, treatment approaches, and outcomes
For detailed information on adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, see  Clinical Review… Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis  : CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708465

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Signs and symptoms of scoliosis –Lateral curvature of the spine greater than 10°. Structural curves have a rotatory component that is seen with forward trunk flexion. Nonstructural curves correct with lateral trunk flexion(4) –Muscle spasms  –Asymmetrical ribs, shoulders, or pelvis –Although not typically a primary complaint, one-third  of adolescents complain of back pain(10) –Severe curves of the spine can impact cardiopulmonary function(2) –Antalgic gait

Congenital scoliosis –Rare and when present generally is detected in the baby’s first year; greater incidence in females than males(3) –Patients with congenital scoliosis have a high incidence of cardiac and urinary tract dysfunction(2) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Functional–Causes include but are not limited to muscle spasm and leg-length  discrepancy(14)

Structural–Most cases are idiopathic (90%)(2)–Causes of congenital scoliosis include malformation of the vertebrae such as hemivertebrae, wedge vertebrae, failure ofsegmentation–Neuromuscular scoliosis occurs in patients with neurologic or musculoskeletal disorders such as cerebral palsy, Duchennemuscular dystrophy, myelomeningocele, spinal muscular atrophy, Friedrich ataxia, spinal cord injury(1)–The most common form of adult scoliosis is degenerative. Older patients are more likely to have newly diagnosedscoliosis secondary to degenerative diseases (e.g., secondary to disc impairment)(18)
pathogenesis: Functional–Lateral curve is reversible(14)–Curve can be corrected through changes in position (e.g., forward flexion of the trunk or correction ofleg-length discrepancy(14))

Structural–Congenital scoliosis is associated with abnormal development in the embryo and can occur in association withdevelopmental abnormalities in other organ systems(16)–Neuromuscular scoliosis is sometimes associated with spasticity or flaccidity depending on upper or lower motor neuroninvolvement–Scoliosis generally manifests in the thoracic and lumbar spine. The following musculoskeletal changes occur:-Rotation of the vertebrae (body) in the direction of the convexity of the curve(10)-Rib hump on the side of the back with the convexity of the curve(10)-The vertebrae take on a wedge shape, with the wider portion on the convex side(4)-Muscle length is reduced on the concave side of the curve(4)-Gravity promotes progression of the curve

Patients with idiopathic scoliosis typically have an imbalance of the paraspinal muscles, with lower electromyographicactivity on the concave side(5)–Histological study of muscle tissue in the concavity shows a lower proportion of slow-twitch  (type 1) fibers. Since thefunction of healthy paraspinal muscles is predominantly postural, requiring tonic activity of type 1 muscle fibers, thissuggests there may be decreased tonic activity in the concavity of the curve(5)
risk factors: Growth hormone secretion(6)–Periods of increased growth hormone secretion is related to increased curve progression

overall contraindications precautions: There are no specific contraindications/precautions for physical therapy related to this condition, but this should be evaluated on an individual basis
It is important to always respect the person’s self-reported  pain level
Patients should be referred back to their physician in the presence of the following red flag symptoms: Bowel/bladder changes Signs of infection Night pain
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was curve first noted and by whom? Are there any associated signs and symptoms? If so, when did they begin? What symptoms are being experienced? Is the patient having difficulty with any activities? Is the curvature worsening and, if so, at what rate? Has pubertal growth spurt started? Has menarche occurred? Is there a family history of scoliosis?

course of treatment.medical management: Structural scoliosis treatment might consist of observation, bracing, or surgery.(3,10) The severity/progression of the curve, skeletal maturity, sex, and age of the patient generally are used to determine method of treatment(4) Children who are physiologically immature (Risser grades 03, premenarchal to 6 months postmenarchal)(11) < 10°  not considered scoliosis 1020°   recommend observation only and follow-up  every 46 months with X-ray  when rib asymmetry > 7º by scoliometry 2030°   consider treatment, especially if progression is observed 3040°   bracing is indicated and must occur immediately > 4045°   surgery likely indicated
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? There are no specific pharmacologic treatments for scoliosis
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:

To measure the Cobb angle, find the end vertebrae of the curve, draw a line parallel to the end plate of each end vertebra, and draw a line perpendicular to each of these lines; the Cobb angle is angle formed by intersection of the perpendicular lines(2,12)
Extremely sensitive indicator of skeletal maturity
Indicates progression of ossification from lateral to medial direction of iliac crest
0 to 5 scale  0 indicates no ossification; 5 indicates complete fusion
Assess for presence of hemivertebrae, fused ribs, or other congenital spine abnormalities(16)
Chest X-ray   when scoliosis is present
Ribs will be widely spaced and rotated posteriorly on the convex portion of the spine, creating a hump
Spaces between the ribs on the concave aspect will be narrowed and ribs will be rotated anteriorly
Cardiac and pulmonary function tests may be performed when greater curvature is present(3)
Preoperative imaging might include CT myelogram or MRI as appropriate
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating or easing factors such as prolonged sitting or standing, gait, or overhead activities
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Many children are asymptomatic -Neuromuscular scoliosis can be detected through abnormal neurological signs (e.g., impaired strength, ataxia, bowel/ bladder impairment)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Use Oucher Scale or Wong-Baker FACES Pain Rating Scale
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to condition. Is there any night pain?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder dysfunction, shortness of breath, saddle anesthesia, muscle weakness, headache, neck pain, or other symptoms suggestive of neurological etiology). Are there any cardiac or urinary tract issues?(2)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise? Does the patient require assisted ventilation? In severe cases the patient might experience breathing changes Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe __________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Other spinal disorders or musculoskeletal injuries? Any neuromuscular disorders? Is there a history of lower limb fracture or arthritis that may result in a leglength discrepancy?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient/caregiver about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, osteoporosis, cardiopulmonary disease, psychiatric disorders, spinal cord injury, kidney disease, congenital defects, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient/caregiver about other symptoms he/she is experiencing. Increased suicidal thoughts and selfimage  concerns have been reported

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient a student? Employed? What are the job requirements? What does the patient spend most of his or her day doing? Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Are there gait or other functional impairments? Impairments in ADLs? Does the patient require the need of assistive or adaptive equipment for functional mobility and ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about home layout, including stairs, number of floors in home, stairs to enter home, and with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Is the patient able to access his or her community with ease (drive, public transportation)?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight and compare with normal growth curves –Loss of height is indicative of curve progression. A notable change in clothing fit might also indicate curve progression  –Assess for a leg-length  discrepancy(2)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess for need, appropriate fit, and appropriate use
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance in sitting and standing. Use the Tinetti Gait and Balance Assessment (TGBA) Scale, Berg Balance Scale (BBS), Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS), or balance sections of the Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)  or Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess cardiopulmonary function for dyspnea on exertion, shortness of breath. Cardiopulmonary impairments are most likely to be associated with severe scoliotic curves
Monitor vital signs as indicated (at rest, during activity, after activity)
Use 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) and Dyspnea Scale of Exertion •Ergonomics/body mechanics:  Assess limitations secondary to spinal deformity
Patients with severe scoliosis might require the use of a wheelchair
Contoured or custom seating systems that align the trunk may be used

Assess ability to perform ADLs and work activities using proper posture and body mechanics. Workstation modifications can be helpful •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.): Complete a general assessment as indicated. The Oswestry Disability Score or the FIM can be used
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Assess the patient’s ability to ambulate safely and efficiently. Note any asymmetry with stride or step length, Trendelenburg, decreased hip extension/flexion, or decreased cadence –Assess endurance and safety and for the presence of abnormal gait patterns. Use the Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) testAssess bilateral upper and lower extremity joints and spinal mobility, noting areas of hyper- or hypomobility, using the Paris Stoddard ScaleAssess bilateral upper and lower extremity and trunk muscle tone, noting any hypo-  or hypertonicity. Use the Modified Ashworth Scale for spasticity as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) for bilateral upper and lower extremities and trunkAssess gross motor skills using the PDMS-2  or BOT-2
observation inspection palpation includi: Look for skin abnormalities such as café au lait spots, pigmentation, or hairy patches (signs of neurofibromatosis). The curve may be the first sign of another underlying syndrome.Other conditions such as neurofibromatosis are associated with a specific curve pattern that can rapidly progress(10)
Assess skin integrity for breakdown or dermatitis associated with bracing. Palpate spinous processes to assess alignment(2)
Inspect surgical site for any signs of infection or improper healing
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess in standing/sitting for presence, type of curve; assess severity and direction. Standing forward flexion test using scoliometer –A plumb line dropped from the occiput or C7 spinous process is useful for detecting minor curves. Inspect the spine for deviations from this line(8) –Observe for postural asymmetries such as asymmetrical scapula height, skin folds, iliac crests, genu valgus/varus, calcaneal valgus/varus(4) –Assess for abnormalities of thoracic kyphosis or cervical or lumbar lordosis
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremity AROM. Can use an inclinometer for measuring trunk extension, flexion, and lateral flexion –Complete a thorough muscle flexibility assessment, especially of the gastrocnemius/soleus, iliopsoas, hamstrings, hip extensors, and pectorals
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess bilateral upper and lower deep tendon reflexes; assess abdominal reflex.Note any asymmetry or abnormalityRefer to occupational therapist for assessment as appropriate, especially in patients with more severe and debilitating deformity
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess dermatomes in the trunk and lower extremities. Perform a detailed assessment if neurological symptoms are present
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –The Adams forward bending test – Patient bends at the waist, 45° forward, arms toward floor(10) -Examiner stands behind patient and looks for elevated and rotated segments -Rotation at the thoracic level causes the ribs to elevate on the side of the curve apex, most often on the right side -Ideally, a scoliometer should be used instead of visual or palpable description alone in order to measure the degree of curvature; the scoliometer is placed at the apex of the deformity while the patient is in the forward-bend  position -Refer to an orthopedist or patient’s physician if there is ≥ 7° curvature

contraindications precautions: Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
other: The clinician should obtain physician’s orders (e.g., weight-bearing status/ability to ambulate) following surgery(4)

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy can be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(9)

Patients with this diagnosis may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Postural deviations, impaired strength, limited ROM, impaired function/ADLs, gait deviations, impaired balance, reduced cardiopulmonary fitness, and pain The patient may also be referred for postsurgical management
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Leg-length  discrepancy, neurofibromatosis, Marfan's syndrome, polio, cerebral palsy, and myelomeningocele Functional scoliosis (e.g., pain that results in splinting) When back pain is present, consider herniation of nucleus pulposus, spinal infection, discitis, facet syndrome, or other causes of low back pain
prognosis: Curve progression is more likely in females than males(2)

The risk of curve progression is related to the size of the curve and the patient’s maturity. In adolescents, curves < 20° will improve spontaneously more than 50% of the time(2) –Surgery is indicated for idiopathic curves > 45° in an immature skeleton  –The larger the curve, the higher the risk of progression regardless of maturity(2)

Prognosis for neuromuscular scoliosis depends on severity of the underlying condition and on maturity –Compared to idiopathic scoliosis, curves are more likely to progress(17) –There is a significant chance of progression in the presence of severe neurological disease (e.g., in patients who are nonambulatory)(17) –May lead to thoracic insufficiency syndrome(17)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Occupational therapy for ADL deficits Physician to evaluate need for brace Wheelchair seating specialist as indicated Orthotist for bracing Pain management
treatment summary: Conservative management –Goal is to prevent worsening of the curve(4) –Treatment may consist of therapeutic exercise and bracing(4) –Bracing -Indications -Used for patients with an immature skeleton who have a scoliotic curve of 25° to 45°(2) -Risser grade of 0–2 and curve progression of 5° over the course of 1 year -Risser grade of 0–2 and scoliotic curve ≥ 30° -Challenges associated with bracing -Family compliance -G-tube -Sensitive skin or other skin problems -Severe respiratory impairments -Behavioral disorder

Surgery/postsurgical therapeutic management –Surgery is indicated for a scoliotic curve > 45° in adolescents(2) –The goal of surgical intervention is to reduce the severity of the curve as able and prevent further progression(4) –Physical therapy treatment in these patients generally consists of respiratory training, mobility training, orthotic instruction, and strengthening as indicated(4) -Inspiratory muscle training can improve pulmonary dysfunction enough to allow surgery in some patients

Therapeutic exercises –Based on a 2020 systematic review, there is insufficient evidence to support the use of scoliosis-specific  exercises to reduce Cobb angle, improve trunk balance, or increase quality of life in patients with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis(19) –Based on an RCT in China, in patients with adolescent idiopathic scoliosis orthotic intervention combined with scoliosis-specific  exercise results in better Cobb angle improvement, pulmonary function, and back muscle endurance compared to orthotic intervention without exercise(20) –Core-based  exercise may help reduce Cobb angle and improve quality of life in patients with scoliosis(21) -No significant difference was found in the angle of trunk rotation post intervention -Nine studies with 325 participants were included in the data ›. effective management of progressing scol: Measurements of scoliotic curves (e.g., scoliometer measurement)
improved functional mobility: The Scoliosis Research Society–22  health-related  quality of life questionnaire (SRS-22  HRQL)

maintenance or prevention: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force concluded there is insufficient evidence to assess the benefit or harm of routine screening of asymptomatic children and adolescents for idiopathic scoliosis.(13) Currently the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Scoliosis Research Society, and the Pediatric Orthopedic Society of North America still support school screenings for scoliosis
